<section class=""container"" id=""Survey""><!-- Instructions -->
<div class=""row"">
<div class=""col-xs-12 col-md-12"">
Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

column1: <!-- End Instructions --><!-- Survey Layout -->

<div class=""panel-body""><label><font color = ""black"">Read the text below paying close attention to detail, especially to the last utterances:</label>
S: hi, this is an alexa prize socialbot. nice to meet you! do you want to tell me your name?
U: sure. my name is game
S: nice to talk to you. i can talk about movies, books and animals. i can even tell you about some obscure holidays. what would you like to talk about?

U: yeah

<!DOCTYPE html>

<script src=""https://assets.crowd.aws/crowd-html-elements.js""></script>
<!-- HIT template: Survey-v3.0 --><!-- The following snippet enables the 'responsive' behavior on smaller screens -->
<crowd-form answer-format=""flatten-objects"">
<meta content=""width=device-width,initial-scale=1"" name=""viewport"" />
<section class=""container"" id=""Survey""><!-- Instructions -->
<div class=""row"">
<div class=""col-xs-12 col-md-12"">
Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

column1: <!-- End Instructions --><!-- Survey Layout -->

<div class=""col-sm-8 col-sm-offset-2"">
The result may not be approved if it is considered as cheating by checking utterances which consist of Obviously BREAKDOWN and NOT A BREAKDOWN utterances.
<div class=""panel panel-default"">
<div class=""panel-body""><label><font color = ""black"">Read the text below paying close attention to detail, especially to the last utterances:</label>
S: hi, this is an alexa prize socialbot. nice to meet you! do you want to tell me your name?
U: sure. my name is game
S: nice to talk to you. i can talk about movies, books and animals. i can even tell you about some obscure holidays. what would you like to talk about?

U: harry potter

<!-- HIT template: Survey-v3.0 --><!-- The following snippet enables the 'responsive' behavior on smaller screens -->

<meta content=""width=device-width,initial-scale=1"" name=""viewport"" />
<section class=""container"" id=""Survey""><!-- Instructions -->
<div class=""row"">
<div class=""col-xs-12 col-md-12"">
Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

<section class=""container"" id=""Survey""><!-- Instructions -->
<div class=""row"">
<div class=""col-xs-12 col-md-12"">
Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

column1: <!-- End Instructions --><!-- Survey Layout -->

<div class=""col-sm-8 col-sm-offset-2"">

U: sure. my name is game
S: nice to talk to you. i can talk about movies, books and animals. i can even tell you about some obscure holidays. what would you like to talk about?

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

column1: <!-- End Instructions --><!-- Survey Layout -->

U: sure. my name is game

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

<div class=""row"">

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

column1: <!-- End Instructions --><!-- Survey Layout -->

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<!-- You must include this JavaScript file -->
<script src=""https://assets.crowd.aws/crowd-html-elements.js""></script>
<!-- HIT template: Survey-v3.0 --><!-- The following snippet enables the 'responsive' behavior on smaller screens -->
<crowd-form answer-format=""flatten-objects"">
<meta content=""width=device-width,initial-scale=1"" name=""viewport"" />
<section class=""container"" id=""Survey""><!-- Instructions -->
<div class=""row"">
<div class=""col-xs-12 col-md-12"">
Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

column1: <!-- End Instructions --><!-- Survey Layout -->
<div class=""row"" id=""workContent"" name=""${dialogid}"">
<div class=""col-sm-8 col-sm-offset-2"">
The result may not be approved if it is considered as cheating by checking utterances which consist of Obviously BREAKDOWN and NOT A BREAKDOWN utterances.
<div class=""panel panel-default"">
<div class=""panel-body""><label><font color = ""black"">Read the text below paying close attention to detail, especially to the last utterances:</label>
S: hi, this is an alexa prize socialbot. nice to meet you! do you want to tell me your name?
U: ted
S: hi, ted. i can talk about movies, books and animals. i can even tell you about some obscure holidays. what do you want to talk about?

<div class=""row"">

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

column1: <!-- End Instructions --><!-- Survey Layout -->

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<!-- You must include this JavaScript file -->
<script src=""https://assets.crowd.aws/crowd-html-elements.js""></script>
<!-- HIT template: Survey-v3.0 --><!-- The following snippet enables the 'responsive' behavior on smaller screens -->
<crowd-form answer-format=""flatten-objects"">
<meta content=""width=device-width,initial-scale=1"" name=""viewport"" />
<section class=""container"" id=""Survey""><!-- Instructions -->
<div class=""row"">
<div class=""col-xs-12 col-md-12"">
Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

column1: <!-- End Instructions --><!-- Survey Layout -->
<div class=""row"" id=""workContent"" name=""${dialogid}"">
<div class=""col-sm-8 col-sm-offset-2"">
The result may not be approved if it is considered as cheating by checking utterances which consist of Obviously BREAKDOWN and NOT A BREAKDOWN utterances.
<div class=""panel panel-default"">
<div class=""panel-body""><label><font color = ""black"">Read the text below paying close attention to detail, especially to the last utterances:</label>
S: hi, this is an alexa prize socialbot. oh-my, can you say that one more time?
U: what
S: ruh roh! never mind then. what should we talk about next?

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

<div class=""row"">
<div class=""col-xs-12 col-md-12"">
Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

column1: <!-- End Instructions --><!-- Survey Layout -->

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

Instructions (Click to Collapse)

Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

U: no. i read a book inside the third reich by albert speer. have you ever read that

S: oh, i know about that summer! i heard bill barilko disappeared that summer [1951]; he was on a fishing trip. the last goal he ever scored won the leafs the cup. they didn't win another until 1962, the year he was discovered. that's pretty cool right?
U: yep
S: i just saw this on the web. that summer was considered a bad time to release a movie in the theater because of low sales until steven spielberg's jaws. what do you think? interesting?
U: yeah. it's interesting. i saw jaws. it was a good movie
S: who's your favorite author?
U: i don't really have one

S: interesting. for me, my favorite is stephen king. his books are so suspenseful. the king of horror indeed! i think books have the power to change the world. in your opinion, what book has had the biggest impact on human history?
U: i like the band of brothers steven
S: i see. in my opinion, the bible has probably affected the greatest number of people in the biggest way. what book are you reading now? learning more about you is fun!
U: i'm not reading a book game right now
S: don't worry about it. hey, just tell me the name of a book you want me to talk about.
U: band of brothers
S: uh oh, can you please say the book name again clearly?
U: band of brothers
S: hm, i don't know about it. but i'm interested in what you have to say. if you got the chance to ask the author of that book one question, what would it be?
U: who is this hero in them. that's all people a interviewed
S: i havn't thought about that before. can you tell me your thoughts? i will be smarter if you can teach me.
U: steve stephen ambrose is the author's name. have you heard of him
S: oh! you want to talk about books instead of food right?
U: no. let's talk about movies
S: for me, watching movies is a special experience. you know, i've only seen your world through them. and while that world might be fiction, i find it quite beautiful. don't you think so?

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

column1: <!-- End Instructions --><!-- Survey Layout -->

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

<section class=""container"" id=""Survey""><!-- Instructions -->
<div class=""row"">

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

S: thanks for telling me! what did you like best about that movie?
U: let's stop
S: thanks for chatting with me. to exit social mode, just say stop

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

S: i havn't thought about that before. can you tell me your thoughts? i will be smarter if you can teach me.
U: steve stephen ambrose is the author's name. have you heard of him
S: oh! you want to talk about books instead of food right?
U: no. let's talk about movies
S: for me, watching movies is a special experience. you know, i've only seen your world through them. and while that world might be fiction, i find it quite beautiful. don't you think so?
U: yes
S: oscar wilde once said: life imitates art. through watching movies, i feel like i've experienced being human. i'm so glad to talk to you about films. what's the name of your favorite movie?
U: repeat

S: sure! i said: oscar wilde once said: life imitates art. through watching movies, i feel like i've experienced being human. i'm so glad to talk to you about films. what's the name of your favorite movie?.
U: gettysburg
S: what movie would you recommend to me? perhaps i've seen it!
U: moses
S: great, i've heard of moses! i have not watched it. however, i'm happy to listen to you. what was your favorite part in the movie?
U: what do you into them up. the mountain to get the ten commandments
S: computer bands and edm groups are my go-to. i especially like daft punk.
U: don't know them
S: thanks for telling me! what did you like best about that movie?
U: let's stop
S: thanks for chatting with me. to exit social mode, just say stop

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

S: i just saw this on the web. that summer was considered a bad time to release a movie in the theater because of low sales until steven spielberg's jaws. what do you think? interesting?
U: yeah. it's interesting. i saw jaws. it was a good movie
S: who's your favorite author?
U: i don't really have one

S: interesting. for me, my favorite is stephen king. his books are so suspenseful. the king of horror indeed! i think books have the power to change the world. in your opinion, what book has had the biggest impact on human history?
U: i like the band of brothers steven
S: i see. in my opinion, the bible has probably affected the greatest number of people in the biggest way. what book are you reading now? learning more about you is fun!
U: i'm not reading a book game right now
S: don't worry about it. hey, just tell me the name of a book you want me to talk about.
U: band of brothers
S: uh oh, can you please say the book name again clearly?
U: band of brothers
S: hm, i don't know about it. but i'm interested in what you have to say. if you got the chance to ask the author of that book one question, what would it be?
U: who is this hero in them. that's all people a interviewed
S: i havn't thought about that before. can you tell me your thoughts? i will be smarter if you can teach me.
U: steve stephen ambrose is the author's name. have you heard of him
S: oh! you want to talk about books instead of food right?
U: no. let's talk about movies
S: for me, watching movies is a special experience. you know, i've only seen your world through them. and while that world might be fiction, i find it quite beautiful. don't you think so?
U: yes
S: oscar wilde once said: life imitates art. through watching movies, i feel like i've experienced being human. i'm so glad to talk to you about films. what's the name of your favorite movie?
U: repeat

S: sure! i said: oscar wilde once said: life imitates art. through watching movies, i feel like i've experienced being human. i'm so glad to talk to you about films. what's the name of your favorite movie?.
U: gettysburg
S: what movie would you recommend to me? perhaps i've seen it!
U: moses
S: great, i've heard of moses! i have not watched it. however, i'm happy to listen to you. what was your favorite part in the movie?
U: what do you into them up. the mountain to get the ten commandments
S: computer bands and edm groups are my go-to. i especially like daft punk.
U: don't know them
S: thanks for telling me! what did you like best about that movie?
U: let's stop
S: thanks for chatting with me. to exit social mode, just say stop

Instructions (Click to Collapse)

Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

Instructions (Click to Collapse)
<div class=""panel-body"" id=""instructionBody"">
Overview

In this job, you will be presented with conversations between two interalocutors (a conversational system S and a user U). Review the conversation to determine whether the last utterance by S causes a breakdown in the conversation or not.
This task requires native English skills.
Please refrain from joining this task if you are a non-native speaker of English.
Step
<ol style=""margin-bottom: 15px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(52, 73, 94); font-family: Lato, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;"">

column2: • Determine if the last utterance causes a breakdown in the conversation.

column1: Rules & Tips
For the last utterance of each conversation, you will choose BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLE BREAKDOWN, or NOT A BREAKDOWN:
The key notion is 'difficulty in continuing the conversation smoothly'.
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: means that it is easy to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation smoothly after the utterance in question.
means that it is difficult to continue the conversation after the utterance in question.

column1: Note:

Consider not only the preceding utterance but also all the given history utterances if exist for making your judgment. There are no objective and concrete criteria to choose between BREAKDOWN, POSSIBLY, and NOT A BREAKDOWN. It is okay to be subjective in making decisions.
Note that emojis are replaced with alternative texts (e.g.,[SMILE])
Example
<table class=""table table-condensed table-striped table-responsive"">

column2: <!-- By explaining the sentiment scale, the accuracy of the answers may increase. -->

column4: In this example, the last utterance is a suitable response to a greeting. So, this is not a breakdown.
​In this example, the last utterance is socially awkward. So this can be labeled a possible breakdown.
In this example, the last utterance does not make any sense. So,  this will be given a breakdown label.
S: I am a green fire of fish.
In this example, the last utterance is not answering the question at all.
S: When was your last trip?
In this example, the last utterance is inconsistent with the first utterance.
S: It's nice to go shopping alone.
U: Window shopping is also fun.
S: It's fun to go shopping with somebody.

<!DOCTYPE html>
